They'll work together to escape and to kill/fight during a riot or skirmish. I find it perfect that I can section off gang members between cell blocks, And one day open up the doors and watch the murder spree insue, Before sending my armed guards set to free-fire in to crap on the resistance.  2, Mods.  With this game you can see almost anything anytime with mods, I once had a mod that is sadly out of date now, Which set the base agression of the prisoners to near-riot at all times. Me moving one prisoner to another cell set off the entire prison into a rampage. Total death toll was over 400 prisoners, 300 guards and the 5 admins, Whom, Got rushed by gun-weilding gangs.  3, Armed Guards.  The fact I can turn my prison into a DPRK Political Prison is just great. Putting guards in the canteena with free-fire on is possibly the best way to maintain order in my prisons while keeping the quality as low as it can possibly go. No janitors, No health care, NOTHING.  Those were the things I like about this game, Time to get into the stuff I hate.  1, Workers.  The workers get stuck far to often for their own good, It seriously calls into question what the level of education required for their field of work is. I once had about 50 workers stuck behind a wall, and 20 more in another. The sad thing is, When i tried to free them, The oposite set would be assigned to free the other. This lasted 20 mins before i hired 100 more.  They also have a tendency to shove their faces into the edge of the map once you buy a gate, Its annoying.  2, Easy to trigger prisoners.  Now, I did say before that I had a mod that triggered them, But it seems the mod is useless now, The prisoners in this game seem to be like their personality was taken straight from forums dedicated to complaints and petty ♥♥♥♥♥. The prisoners can be set off for litterally walking to far. Its rediculas when you have to kill half your prison beacuse they hate WALKING.  3, Cell Quality.  This is a prison, Not a luxury hotel. The Campaign (which also serves as the tutorial) opens with a prison that isn't quite finished yet. And you are told by your boss, the CEO of the 'For Profit' Prison, that you have been given the task of executing a murderer. And this order comes from the state itself.  The game then turns towards teaching you how to work the basic construction tools, explaining power, water, foundations, interior walls, and room basics in a straightforward and clean manner.  Then the game shows you exactly why your prisoner is guilty.  It is not a pleasant experience to watch as a tiny cartoon man walk into his home, find his tiny cartoon wife ♥♥♥♥ing a tiny cartoon stranger in his bed, and then tearfully shoot them both in the head.  This gives us the biggest lesson of all: Prison Architect is not a happy game.  Prison Architect is a top down management game where you run your prison company exactly how you want it. As far as the state is concerned, it doesn't matter how high your rehabilitation rate is, all that matters is that you have no escapes, keep the deaths to an acceptable low, and you keep the prisoners in line by any means you deem fit.  Once you finish your campaign, which takes you through the systems of the game, explaining core concepts quite happily while also telling you tales of loss, pain, murder, ambition, hope, and sheer murderous rage. Of course, the problem is that the game ONLY explains the core mechanics and leaves more complicated ones for you to figure out yourself. That said, while there is a Wiki and many a guide for you, the point of the core game in sandbox mode is mostly to see what works best. To adapt to problems and overcome even of it must be done through trail, error and blood.  The game provides security measures such as cameras, remote doors opened by a button or a timer, stab vests and tazers for your guards, and even heavily armed maximum force response teams kept on site with shotguns, full body armor, and the will and means to paint your prison red with blood at your command. Along with this the game will provide schedules, assignments, patrols, and even resticted acess zoning, all of which is designed to keep your prisoners under control so they do not kill each other.  Along with this is provided many means to turn your prisoners into peaceful members of society if you so choose. You may provide basic education, as many prisoners lack even a child's reading and writing skills. And some of them cannot even read at all, let alone write. Give your prisoners trade skills as carpenters or metal workers. Teach them how to be cleaners or work a laundry. And then set up security systems to prevent prisoners stealing hammers or making crude knives.  Prisoners may come with medical issues such as addiction, alchoholism or violent pshycological instability. Build a common room for AA meetings, an office for one on one meetings for professional mental help, an infirmary for chemical treatmeants to help with addiction and minor surgery when the prisoners try to kill, and a mourge when they do kill.  Your prisoners are humans, with desires and needs, thoughts and feelings, and intelligence. Prisoners need to be fed, and you may give them things to do. Build a common room with tables, television sets, and phones. Provide meals at preset times, as many times as you want, in large quantaties and variety if you want, or a simple bowl of vegetable soup once a day if you don't. Prisoners with many things to do are less likey to cause trouble, and giving them these things may make them very happy indeed.  This does not mean you may treat them like sane members of society. You are running a prison. They are prisoners. And Prisoners are not in the habit of obeying the rules. Prisoners steal, fight, and even kill in your walls. Make no mistake, you and your officers are the only order inside the prison. Without your constant watchful gaze and omnipresent guards the prisoners will fall upon each other like wild animals; killing, fighting, and breaking.  If your prisoners are exceptionally angry, and if your prison is weak enough, the prisoners may decide that they can do whatever thy want and there is nothing you can do about it. They may decide to riot. Or you may subdue them, show them that any antisocial behaviour will not be tolerated, and make them docile through fear.  Problems may arise in your prison, and of course these are optional. Make it so that he game throws problems your way at random. Maybe a highly contagious disease is rampaging through your prison and killing your prisoners. Perhaps a water main has burst. Maybe a generator has overloaded, causing a fire and a blackout. Or maybe the mayor has bowed to political pressure and decided to implement reform without consulting you.  If you feel particularly brave, allow the game to generate gangs, and watch as your prison becomes split by three gangs into territories, and attempt to usurp your authority. And then spiral into gang wars, burn your prison down, kill your guards, and extort prisoners.  Prison Architect, ultimately, is exactly what it says it is, with a remarkable and well made game that most will like. BUt do not expect to laugh because of the cutesy graphics.   They mitigate the horror, but only make it bearable.

I would recommend this game since I really like the concept and it's fascinating to see your prison run itself. It gives a bit of a Settlers vibe. However as they consider this game finished (It's not early access anymore), demand 28€ for it and announced the next update to be the last big one I cannot give it a recommendation. It just isn't done yet, and if you play for longer, the unfinished, unrefined and outright frustrating parts - none of which will be fixed by the update - will hit you in the face like a train. I'll list a few of those:  - The temperature system is a complete afterthought and not done well at all. You can only lower temperature by having windows, and raise it with radiators. If your kitchen isn't adjacent to an outside wall, it will overheat constantly, and windows are always open, leading to your prisoners freezing in the winter. Radiators also can't be turned off in the summer. AC? Never heard of it.  - The game rewards badly managed prisons over well managed ones. Prisoner deaths are not punished directly, technically they're even rewarded because they make room for new prisoners. Even if you have failure conditions activated, the chance of feeling actual punishment is low. What is punished are 'incidents', which even a well run prison can barely avoid, especially with gangs activated. I can only say that I tried both, and the prison where I stuffed 300+ prisoners into a 120m² holding cell certainly rolled in dosh.  - The calculations for dormitories have been broken forever. A dormitory with 3 inhabitants and 1 TV doesn't count as '1 TV per 4 prisoners'. You have to have at least, I think, 5 prisoners in a dormitory for the calculations to hold up, which of course increases the chances of the inmates shanking each other.  - Click, click, click, click. This game requires so much ♥♥♥♥ing clicking. The scroll speed is brutally slow so you have to click and drag with the middle mouse button to get around. And the developers apparently never heard of hotkeys, because you have to click to do absolutely anything. There are thousands of management and economy games that did it better. This game will murder your carpal tunnel.  - Prisoner behaviour is disappointingly primitive. You'd think putting the power generator somewhere isolated and under guard makes sense because prisoners will try to sabotage it - they don't. You'd think they try to sneak into the storage room to steal some tools - they don't. I once tried a huge prison full of security flaws - the armory right next to the canteen with no walls in between, power generators out in the open... nothing happened. Not a single prisoner stole a weapon, or did anything else but get into minor fisticuffs with the guards.  - Room assignment is painfully broken. Basically, whenever you add a room somewhere, the game sees it as 'reassign EVERYTHING to Shared' and then suddenly you have max security prisoners in your min security block, cells in unfinished wings being occupied and prisoners strolling around the outskirts of your prison. This is obviously a hyperbole but seriously, you will suffer at least half a dozen escapes from this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.  - Deliveries will mess you up. More specifically, mail deliveries. If your prisoners can't keep up sorting the mail, it will at some point just overflow your delivery area. And what does the delivery driver do if there's no more room for his mail? Why of course, he will just stay there and block the road for everything else - like food deliveries or prisoner buses. Solution for this? Click on a mail bag, click dump. Click on a mail bag, click dump...  - The prisoner intake is convoluted and counterintuitive as hell. Something extremely simple like 'Give me 1 delivery of X medium security and Y maximum security prisoners' can't be done. Instead there are 'Fill to X' and 'X per day' settings where the security level is determined in percentages. This has lead to me forgetting to close my prison and ending up with way too many prisoners so often I lost count.  - The way patrols work is frustratingly idiotic. When finished with its shift, a guard will simply leave its post without waiting for its replacement, leaving your prisoners unguarded.  - Maximum security doors can be destroyed. Fences can't. Your prisoners will outright give up any escape attempts if there's a fence surrounding your perimeter.  - The game barely explains anything. I once tried to dismantle an object in a common room - the button just didn't do anything. Only later I found out that this room was occupied by a gang.  - There's no borderless windowed mode.  - And last but not least, the game - or at least the campaign - implies that you have a choice between running a prison based on fear and one based on making the inmates happy. This dualism may make sense IRL but in this game, it doesn't. If you have a prisoner with a certain set of traits, it becomes outright impossible to contain him. In real life, you'd put someone with 300 murders in his portfolio into a small room with no window and a massive steel door, but in this game, someone can destroy such a door with a single punch of his bare fists, then resist several tazer and shotgun hits and take out half a dozen guards. Then get healed up and do it again and again and again. The only way to avoid this is by making this demigod of a man happy, which in turn means that your SuperMax wing becomes the SuperLuxury wing. If this isn't counterintuitive to you, I don't know what is.
It's the Rollercoaster Tycoon of the modern age.  It's a completely bizzare idea but somehow building and maintaining a prison is damn good fun.

Surprisingly deep game with a cartoony art style that makes the grim reality of prison more palatable. Every Early Access update was a nice step forward, and the 1.0 release definitely feels like a complete game.  Best thing about it, in my opinion, is that this game is incredibly balanced. You can be as harsh as you want, or build luxury suites for your drug dealers and murderers. You can build your favorite prisoner his own home and have staff bring his meals to him while he watches TV all day. All of these are valid playstyles, and will perform well on different metrics.  There are so many different game mechanics going on, but they're all intuitive, and the game's timescale control gives you all the time you need to figure out what to do. The campaign mode also breaks down a lot of the features one-by-one, which makes a great introduction to the game.

There are a few reasons to recommend this game (It's novel and fun at first, if you're into planning and optimizing) and many reasons not to (Bugs, poor design decisions, it's far too easy/lacks complexity, it's not yet finished but 'released' from EA, balancing issues, ...).  I originally planned to write a detailed review, expanding on each issue, but decided against it as to not steal focus from the one big reason I'm writing this non-recommendation:    MAJOR PERFORMANCE ISSUES

Well, Prison Architect is finally released. I've been with prison architect for a while now and let me say. They haven't let me down. The game used to be really bugyy, filled with little loopholes, AI problems, or simply backed up supply coming in. The core game was always there. For that I stuck with the game. I'll give you a little bit of a summary (?) on the game in general.  Gameplay: As you can clearly see, I've played this game a LOT. Built tons of prisons, messed around with prisoners, built a sandbox prison. I did almost everything. Thing is, I'm still into it. This game is BIG on replayabilty. Honestly I think I've built near identical prisons and they never end the same. The game has been lately centered on randomness of the AI. You used to be able to run the game overnight and nothing would happen. The game has now made it that you will have to pay attention to everything that happens in the game. Riots, drug overdoses, escaping prisoners, angry prisoners, tired guards, you name it.   Mechanics: The game has quite a few interesting mechanics on it. One being that prisoners actually work togethor on trying to escape, or they will constantly try to get contraband. You can choose to let the prisoners sit in thier cells and have the guards deliver food to them or you can let them run around in the yard and potentially get their 'goods' from the fences. Good food, high costs? Small cells or big cells? Armed guards or normal guards? Lockdown or solitary? The game has a lot of choices for you to make for the prison, and a lot of them have a long lasting effect on your game.  Asthetics: The game is very pleasing to the eye to view, eveyrthing is smooth, and they have worked on getting the graphics to work with each other. The prisoners and guards are different from each other; making them not a stereotypical guard or prisoner. Overall I would say that if you are for some reason worried about the graphics/asthetics or whatever you want to call them; you shouldn't have a problem wiht it.  Humor?: Yes, I won't say too much, but once you see some of the prisoner's stories you will get a good number of laughs.  Realism?: I would say this is a pretty accurate simulation of a prison. Prisoners have basic needs, as well as some extra ones like religion or drugs. Metal detectors detect metal tools and not medicine (duh) while dogs will help you with the actual drugs.  Community: The community is a very funny one, and is overall accepting. No infamous sour community calling you a newb or anything. Most people offer their ideas of a 'perfect' prison, and are usually open to give help or get tips.  Sounds: Well, I would say that the sound effects of the game are pretty accurate when you get near a partifcular room. (Eg. Near a cafeteria you hear eating or silverware when near a prisoner working out you hear him working out) I would say they payed attention to detail but I wouldn't honestly expect stunningly amazing music.  True Sandbox: Definetly is a true sandbox, variety of starting options as well as giving you unlimited funds.  Too Easy? Too Hard?: This one game honestly lets you modify your difficulty. If you want difficult you tell yourself only max prisoners and conditions of losing. New to the game? Take in small amounts of prisoners that are maybe minimum and turn of conditions. It is really up to you how hard you want to make it. If lets say you do 'medium' difficulty then you might find that its more difficult if you messed things up early on or are new to it. It may be easy if you are a pro at sandbox games. I would say if its too easy or too hard its probably you and not the game.  Last comments: Thank you all for reading this review I know it was a lot to take in. I would strongly suggest that you buy this game. The devolpers have worked so hard on this game, they've created hundreds of hours of joy for people and have realeased updates pretty regularily.  Rating: 10/10 I will definetly suggest this to someone else and look into their other games.

As a huge sandbox genre lover Prison Architect has been on my to-play list for quite some time, and I wasn't disappointed after getting it. It's literally what it claims to be - you are an architect of a prison, with the added pleasure of getting to manage it as well. One would think that there is only so much you can do with such an idea, but in this game it has been executed really well so far.  I honestly did not expect what this game actually offers from it. Apart from a few silly problems the mood and psychology of each individual prisoner in your prison are a very nice touch. Some are more troublesome than the others (and you don't usually know that right away, you have to learn it throughout the gameplay) and some may be something like ex-law enforcement and that will make them get in trouble with other prisoners a lot should they not be watched at all times. Unhappy prisoners obviously cause trouble, and that includes the need to see their family, sleep, entertainment, comfort, so on, but even greatly unsatisfied they will be hesitant to do anything if you put armed patrols around them. Or snipers. That creates a great variety of ways in which your prison can be ran - Do you want to have a luxury Swedish prison with bacon and eggs for breakfast every day or would you rather be in charge of a war prison where your prisoners don't even have beds? It's all there.  Your prisoners will also make greater efforts to escape if they feel unhappy in your prison, while, if you treat them well, they almost can't be bothered to do so. They will take the opportunity if the door is open, but can also attempt things like digging tunnels, or even causing riots. It is essential you design your prison well, because a strategic placement of things like main entrance, armoury or door-control systems actually matters in case things go really bad. You can also assign patrols, put metal detectors in chokeholds, instal phone taps, all sorts of things to ensure your prison is secure and contraband-free (because your prisoners will attempt to smuggle it in A LOT).  There is also a campaign mode but there is not a whole lot to it, really. There is a story going on that one could be interested in but it didn't really catch my attention that much; it's basically a tutorial where you learn how things work. I, myself, just stick to the sandbox.  The game obviously has its flaws, but it's constantly getting improved and it's already more than I expected from a would-seem-simplistic sandbox game. I'd say that if I can get 50 hours into just sandboxing and placing walls around without any purpose then somebody had to do something right.

As of Final Release, PA is officially a 'constant revisit' game for me. For those who played once long ago, you may want to seriously consider playing again, considering how many changes they have done (good news, it now also runs with much fewer resources thanks to a fix a few patches ago). If you have not played, and you enjoy sim games that offer some degree of challenge and/or financial consideration, get this game.  A few good points:   AI: The AI is good for this sort of game. The prisoners are hardly genius, but they are crafty. They will arrange drops for smuggled goods, and depending on your prison setup, they will do so in a place where they can grab it as they pass by. They will also do their best to fight and get into mischeif when out of view of cameras and guards.   Complexity: PA hits an excellent point between 'Too simple to be fun (Zoo Tychoo 2)' and 'Too complex to learn (Dwarf Fortress).' It has a basic tutorial, but the grant system used for starting funds is essentially a organized list of prisoner needs, making a true tutorial almost uneeded. Once you master the basics, there are additional options, such as central door controls and cctv cameras, that will allow your prision to become more complicated and potentially effective. Different types of prisoners require different and more complex security, allowing you to go from an easy going low-sec blue coller jail to a max-sec death row full of potentially violent offenders.   Variation: Like the original Zoo Tychoon, PA is a diverse game, in that you can be very creative at what you build (a quick scan of the Workshop can show you the amount of variaty). This adds a lot to replayability.   Respect: The Dev's have treated this game and their customers with respect. This is important, because some of the subjects covered (such as religion and the death penalty) are sometimes touchy subjects. Playing the game, you can see this (especially the death penalty. The system they use is suitably ominous and serious despite the somewhat amusing antics of prisoners at other times).

An intricate and deep simulation with an engaging and thoughtful campaign built on top of it. It's more approachable and has a more gradual learning curve than other games of this nature, while still maintaining complexity. Despite that, it's probably going to require more patience to enjoy than most people (like me) can bear. Its key flaws are due to the complexity of the simulation and the user interaction with that simulation.  I kind of burned out on this game. Once I got to the final campaign mission, it really started to feel like a job or a chore. All I could think about while I was playing is all the work I'm going to have to do to get my prison set up, starting from scratch. I'm going to have to figure out where all the rooms should go, what sizes they should be, and I'm going to have to keep on clicking and clicking and pulling up menus to keep on making progress. It really piles on the decision fatigue and, as I played, I just felt a constant reluctance to do what I know needed to be done because I didn't want to have to navigate through all the menus and options and make all the little small decisions needed to keep building.  The key example of this is building a new prison wing. You need to create the foundation, measure out all the cells, build the cell walls, put all of the crap into each individual cell (bed, toilet, and door for each), build the shower, put all the shower heads in, then run wire so that it can reach each cell, run pipe to the cell block, and run small pipes through all the toilets and all the shower heads. Each of these steps involves clicking through menus, deciding specifics like where things go, exactly how big things should be, and how they should connect. Sounds fun? Not to me. It may sound lame, but I'd honestly rather just wave my hand and say 'this area is the prison area', and have things be taken care of for me.   The feeling I get with this game is the similar to the feeling of reluctance I get when I know I need to do my laundry.  So, I would not recommend this to most people. I'd only recommend it to you if you really are into this sort of game - management, simulation, and building. Otherwise, it's just going to demand too much patience from you in order to really engage with it. At that point, you'll probably be left wondering why you don't just play one of the many other games out there that provide more instant and constant enjoyment and stimulation. It sounds fun on paper (as do most simulations), but it just doesn't translate to consistently and instantly fun gameplay, and, for many people, that's all they are looking for in a game.

There's many rooms you can build and you will (most likely) need all of them, not having a laundry for 10 days can lead to a riot! You will need to constantly expand your prison building territory (which will make you think who would even has to time to build all of that, just building a simple prison for 50 prisoners takes well over 30 minutes, try to do it with a few thousand) unless you have turned off prison intake (yes, you can choose what type of security prisoner you take in, how much, what the ratio is or turn it off 100%). Riots... Because it's too slow, we need a bigger maxinum cloning radius (50 cells should be good enough) to do some good prisons faster. It hits hard when your glorious prison on which ou spent a long time creating just comes crashing down to a simple room thta you could've made in just five minutes.This drags players away from the games' building since it's so confusing. If there is one game I have consistantly come back to over and over again its Prison Archetect.   Prison Archetect is a game that consistantly punishes you to get it right. It's challenge isn't in the campaign mode, or even the sandbox, the challenge is consistently fighting with and against the games well implemented and thought out systems.   Gameplay:: Prison Archetect plays like any good simulator should. It doesn't hold your hand, it simply gives you some prisoners, sets some goals in the form of grants, and lets you attack it however you want. Prisoners have a set of needs, from bladder, to hunger, to spiruality and excercise. How you choose to fulfill or not to, is entirely up to you and where this game shines.  Do you create a state of the art detention center? Where prisoners are given a bed, a toilet, two meals a day and an hour to excersize? Along side this supermax housing unit, you may want to put in a medium security section, where medium risk prisoners work, excersize, trade goods and fight, before you deem them too dangerous and upgrade them to supermax. Over the road, you can have a low security section, where you may want to hold some of your less desireables, such as ex police, and prison guards.  You'll be in charge of every facet of these prisoners lives (each individually named with a background written by kickstarter backers).   Graphics:: The game has a simple 2D art style, the animations are well done, and works well overall.  Sound:: Sound plays an important part in the game, not only adding to the ambience of a prison simulation with cries of terror and the sound of clanking doors but is important to tell when something is about to kick off, or already has based on how your prisoners sound. When treated well, you won't hear much from your prisoners, but forget to hire cooks or cleaners for a few days, and you will begin to hear your prisoners rumble and yell before eventually they will riot.   Overall:: Prison Archetect lets you go as deep and as complicated as you want. Giving you full control on how you want to play, it is a true sandbox of creativity with a whole miriad of systems that simply work. Whether it be the water and electricity system, the smuggling system the prisoners use to sneak in weapons and drugs, or simply just how staff combat this with the steps you put in place to control contraband. Prison archetect is not only a deep simulator, it is constantly updated even after release, by a developer who goes above and beyond for their customers long after they've received your money.   9.5/10

This is probably one of the more unique management games I've played. I give it a solid recommendation.  Both the campaign, and the sandbox mode are enjoyable, however keep in mind that you shouldn't dive head first into trying to build your own prison. While it seems quite easy to make money, poor planning can lead to escapes, 'fog of war' can lead to violence/deaths, and if you haven't gotten a brief idea of how big your buildings/foundations should be, you'll soon find you've wasted quite a bit of space and money. This is why 'architect' is the key word, and not 'tycoon.' Yes you make money and manage the prison, but you have to be careful with your designs.  A final note why I highly recommend it to any management/simulator fans: The sandbox mode is definitely one of the more engaging sandbox modes. Not only does it have handy boxes that monitor important aspects (what % of inmates have been fed, how many tired employees) which means not having to open the ledger every few minutes to make sure you're not going to have a riot, but it uses a system of 'grants' to give you a friendly guide to what buildings to make. While this can make the game a bit easier, because you'll soon find yourself awash in cash, it adds a layer of direction that other sandbox modes (Banished, although great, is the first example that comes to mind) don't have. This means instead of the standard extremely hard beginning, then zen mid-late game, you've got a solid early-mid game set of tasks, and then late game can be focused on upgrading (having more max-security prisoners, installing CCTV, remote doors, prisoner workshops etc)  The only issue I've found so far, which I find strange, but I doubt it'll be an issue in 1-3 months time. There's no 'start' screen. Game loads with a new prison. Should I be at fault for this, I welcome a commentor to let me know to rectify this.  Buy it, don't let the graphics fool you, it's 100% worth the price.

UPDATE Nov. 2, 2015  I'm up to around 60 hours of playtime now and I have my first $2 million prison with over 350 inmates. Yesterday I expanded across the road for the first time. The gameplay has much variety to it, as you can build the prison any way you want and run it how you see fit. It can be tuned more twoard punishment with many armed guards and basic cells, or the goal can be reform, with many programs to help inmates get relase early. Some prisons are visually pleasing, while others are efficient and functional, but ugly.   On my currnet prison, with 350 inmates and around 200 staff members, I find the game lags some. I have a FX-6300 CPU and 16GB of RAM, but I understand the game runs on only a single core.   The biggest bug I see is installing electrical lines in a larger prison. I have six or seven power stations, and almost every time I add to my power lines I get a 'no route' error. I don't understand that as the work men have a clear route to the work site. Sometimes it'll take me 10 minutes to add maybe 20 squares of power lines, which is very frustrating. I hope IV addresses that in a patch.   I plan to continue playing my currnet prison until I feel it's maxed out. I really enjoy the game, but my wife hates that I spent two or three hours at a time playing.

I don't know why the steam version doesn't have a proper ESRB rating (like GTA) but the console version is rated M for Blood, Drug Reference, Partial Nudity, Sexual Content, Strong Language, Violence. The tutorial campaign has scenes of sex & violence. Regular game has avatar nudity for showers and avatar fights/death though you often miss them unless you stop playing the game to look for it.  It's a prison building simulator with a short campaign, free/sandbox mode, and a basic escape mode.  The campaign serves as a tutorial that teaches only the basics. It's only 5 episodes so story is compact, like a framework to a more epic story, showing only the key/best parts. There are several mini-storylines where characters drop out of the story and you never hear from them again.  Grants make a nice quest system to give you objectives you aim for when developing your prison. The money rewards make improving/expanding go smoothly but when the grants run out it's up to you to make your own goals. The end game is up to you to make fun for yourself.  In escape mode, you control one prisoner and try to escape via foot or tunnel, quietly or armed. You can choose any prison (one you make or one from the workshop). It's a very basic mode. You don't need to follow the schedule with other prisoners. Don't need to fulfill any needs. The guards ignore you unless you do something blatantly wrong so you can just fight for more than 2 skill points, get arrested, then use one point to automatically skip the punishment wait and repeat until you max out skills.  Edit: A proper escape mode is like the game 'The Escapist' which has that but no architect simulator.  One thing missing here that I remember in other simulation games (like RollerCoaster Tycoon and Big Pharma) are scenario challenges where you clear a target objective within a certain time (or have other specified goals).  Worth a try if you enjoy simulation/tycoon games.  Other thoughts:    Programs usually autoassign staff and rooms okay but when it doesn't work there's no easy way to fix things. Sometimes dezoning works.    People walk over objects so seems like empty spaces are just for aesthetics to make things look nice.    There should be an indicator (arrow, box, etc.) to show where an object is interacted with (for example, an ironing board needs to be approached from the bottom so it can't be blocked off with a wall). For whatever reason the game doesn't let you fully rotate these interactable objects which means you can't place it as you might want.    There are keyboard shortcuts but there's no way I can find to change them or see the list of what they are.    It would be nice to be able to label rooms while you're planning to help keep track of your layout.    I would've liked the objects menu to be searchable by room and have room tabs to display things useful to the room.    The clone feature is nice but it would be nice to permanently set a template design to quick build later across any save. You can do it manually outside of the game but would be nice to use the in-game UI to do it easily.    I think it's a little weird that you start with a positive cash flow without any prisoners. It means that if you don't care about the time spent (there's no reason to) you can save money at the start by not buying workmen and instead fast forwarding time so you gain more free money before your expenses kick in.    I think it could be interesting for an option to have outside inspections (from the government, etc.) that you need pass occasionally.    There are certain things that should be in UI that you have to look up in the wiki (ex: what affects max jobs in a room, how are license plates made). Even if it's intuitive, it should say what needs the object fulfills (and if certain objects fulfill needs better than others).    There should be a way to reposition objects rather than wait to dismantle then replace.    It would be nice to watch replays of big events that happened (like escapes, possibly fights) because you usually miss the start of it.    It would be nice to click on a need and see a list of prisoners that you can click to zoom in on. That way you could watch and figure out why they're don't getting that need fulfilled.
